facts.text: Defendant was a tenant of the plaintiffs and the rent of the premises in his occupation was Rs. 110 p.m.
Defendant was in arrears of rent from April 1, 1958 to March 31, 1959 to the extent of Rs. 1,020.

On April 11, 1959 the plaintiffs served a notice on the defendant bringing to his notice the fact of his being in arrears of rent for 12 months and requiring him to remit Rs. 1,020 within one month from the date of service of notice and stating that on his failure to do so, a suit for ejectment would be filed against him. In addition, the notice called upon the defendant to vacate the premises by April 30, 1959 upon grounds that the premises were required by the plaintiffs genuinely for business and that the defendant had sublet a portion of the premises to two persons without permission.
Notice dated April 11, 1959 was received by the defendant on April 16, 1959.
On June 25, 1959 the defendant sent a reply to the notice enclosing a cheque for Rs. 1,320, which consisted of the rental arrears as well as the rent due right up to June 30, 1959.
Plaintiffs accepted the cheque and cashed it on July 4, 1959 and stated that they had cashed it under protest.
Plaintiffs gave a fresh notice on July 9, 1959 requiring the defendant to vacate the premises by the end of the month of July.
Defendant did not vacate the premises and the present suit for eviction was instituted on August 14, 1959.
Plaintiffs' claims for eviction on grounds that premises required bona fide for business and illegal subletting were negatived by courts below.
Courts below ordered defendant's ejectment on ground of arrears of rent; Madhya Pradesh High Court dismissed defendant's appeal by judgment dated September 27, 1962 in Second Appeal No. 158 of 1962.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.
Premises situated in Jabalpur where Madhya Pradesh Accommodation Control Act, 1955 is in force.

legal_issues.text: Whether the plaintiffs are entitled to eject the defendant on the ground that he was in arrears of rent for one year and failed to pay within one month of notice dated April 11, 1959, considering validity of notices under s.106 TPA and s.4(a) Accommodation Act, waiver by acceptance of rent, and subsistence of arrears ground at date of suit.
Whether notice dated April 11, 1959 was valid under s.106 of Transfer of Property Act requiring 15 clear days notice expiring at end of month.
Whether default in payment was waived by acceptance of cheque for Rs.1,320, giving fresh notice on July 9, 1959, and filing suit on August 14, 1959 relying on second notice.
Whether arrears ground under s.4(a) must subsist on date of suit.

petitioner_arguments.text: Notice of April 11, 1959 invalid under s.106 TPA as it did not purport to determine tenancy and provided less than 15 clear days notice.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.106 Transfer of Property Act; Subadini v. Durga Charan Lal

petitioner_arguments.text: Default waived by acceptance of Rs.1,320 cheque covering rent up to June 30, 1959, fresh notice July 9, 1959, and suit relying only on second notice.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Waiver; s.113 Transfer of Property Act illustration (a)

petitioner_arguments.text: No arrears on date of suit August 14, 1959, so no cause of action under s.4(a) Accommodation Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.4(a) Madhya Pradesh Accommodation Control Act, 1955

petitioner_arguments.text: Second notice invalid under TPA and Accommodation Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.106 Transfer of Property Act; s.4 Accommodation Act

respondent_arguments.text: Notice April 11, 1959 is composite notice under s.4(a) Accommodation Act and s.106 TPA; to be liberally construed.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.106 TPA; s.4(a) Accommodation Act; Harihar Banerji v. Ramsashi Roy

respondent_arguments.text: Suit based on valid second notice July 9, 1959 which complied with s.106 TPA.
s.4(a) ground does not require arrears to subsist on date of suit; only failure to pay within one month of demand notice.
Acceptance of rent after notice does not waive s.4(a) right as tenancy continued and rent was due.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: No waiver of statutory right under s.4(a)

court_reasoning.text: Provisions of s.4 Accommodation Act are in addition to s.106 TPA; both must be complied with.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Accommodation Act does not abrogate Ch.V TPA.

court_reasoning.text: Notice April 11, 1959 valid under s.4(a) but ineffective under s.106 TPA as only 14 clear days, not 15.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Approves Subadini v. Durga Charan Lal; liberal construction not permissible to deprive tenant of 15 days facility.

court_reasoning.text: Suit competently instituted based on valid July 9 notice complying with s.106 TPA.
s.4(a) does not require arrears to subsist on date of suit; only failure within one month of demand.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Natural meaning of language; distinguishes other Acts.

court_reasoning.text: No waiver by acceptance of rent; tenancy continued post ineffective s.106 notice, rent due monthly.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Acceptance under protest irrelevant; does not waive statutory s.4(a) right.

court_reasoning.text: s.4(a) removes bar to eviction but tenancy remains monthly; no forfeiture under s.111(g) TPA, no s.114 relief applies.

holdings.text: Notice April 11, 1959 ineffective under s.106 TPA but valid for s.4(a) Accommodation Act.
Arrears ground under s.4(a) arises on failure to pay within one month of demand; need not subsist on suit date.
No waiver of s.4(a) right by accepting rent post-notice as tenant liable to pay rent till tenancy terminated.
Plaintiffs entitled to decree for ejectment on s.4(a) ground, suit based on valid July 9 notice.

precedents_cited.relevance: Notice under s.106 TPA must give 15 clear days.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gobinda Chandra Saha v. Dwarka Nath Patita

precedents_cited.relevance: Liberal construction of notices to quit; but not to deprive tenant of 15 days under s.106.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act, 1882
statutes_cited.relevance: s.106 requires 15 days notice to terminate monthly tenancy; s.4 Accommodation Act additional to it; no forfeiture or waiver as argued.

statutes_cited.name: Madhya Pradesh Accommodation Control Act, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Eviction only on specified grounds including failure to pay arrears within one month of demand; ground need not subsist on suit date.

statutes_cited.name: Madhya Pradesh Accommodation Control Act, 1961
statutes_cited.relevance: Contrasted; provides post-suit payment opportunity unlike 1955 Act.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the defendant's appeal, upholding the High Court and lower courts' decree for ejectment on the ground of failure to pay arrears within one month of April 11, 1959 notice under s.4(a) of Madhya Pradesh Accommodation Control Act, 1955, rejecting arguments on notice validity, waiver, and subsistence of arrears.

key_quotes.text: "the test of their sufficiency is not what they would mean to a stranger ignorant of all the facts and circumstances touching the holding to which they purport to refer, but what they would mean to tenants presumably conversant with all those facts and circumstances"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Harihar Banerji; on liberal construction of notices, but distinguished here.

key_quotes.text: "This provision clearly speaks of a tenant having failed to make payment to the landlord of the arrears of rent due from him within the time prescribed in that clause. It does not mean that the ground on which eviction is claimed must subsist till the date of suit."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on s.4(a); arrears failure need not persist to suit date.

key_quotes.text: "the legislature intended to give protection only to a tenant who was diligent and regular enough in the matter of payment of rent."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains limited scope of tenant protection under s.4(a).
